Douglas:  We share a common view on these issues.  Goodness knows, each of us has likely "screwed up" enough ourselves to fill our "guilt" bag.  We sure don't need to take on guilt from other persons and actions over which we had and have no control....i.e. guilt from the past.

However, if we aren't willing to confront actions taking place today which we feel are unjust, it's a different story.  If we sit passively and don't confront such actions we are, IMO, giving our tacit agreement to those actions.  

My focus is on TODAY and what I can do to help....It may just be very small actions, but if I fail to take them, then I feel the guilt of negligence and cowardice.  my regards, Gary

In my travels throughout eastern and southeastern Europe I found that these former communist nations (puppet nations under the old Soviet Union) did not destroy statues of Lenin, Marx, Engels, Stalin, etc etc but, instead, moved them to special parks set aside for educational purposes.  So, the statues and monuments survived but as a lesson to current and future generations concerning the brutal history of past monsters.  Such educational displays help start conversations about how to avoid such brutality in the future and serve as continual reminders of horrific behaviors to be avoided.

We should NEVER glorify past horror with monuments by looking the other way but we must always remember these horrors so as not to repeat them.  Those who forget history are doomed to repeat it.  No one can dispute that Chivington was just one such monster.

Empowered by the response to the Harvey Weinstein revelations, I think many victims of sexual misconduct (or their families) are feeling emboldened to speak out. And when multiple people make allegations against the same person, it’s harder to see it as a coordinated hit job and easier to see a sexual predator revealed. Jail, public shame, lost business… that all kind of depends on the strength and severity of the allegations. 

Re: Moore, this isn’t Rolling Stone relying on one witness and her close friends for a story. It’s the Washington Post relying on multiple, unaffiliated sources. That doesn’t equal 100% veracity or guilt, but that’s a lot of smoke for there to be no fire.

Clearly I never denied a certain unpredictability since I in multiple places mentioned our cooperation.   

I reject the word random however for a very substantial reason.

There's more than chance involved.  There's virtue, which is a natural faculty God invented and put in us:  an ability to grow toward the good.  Virtue happens when good acts are repeated, tending to make our response to God's will less random, and more inclined to the good.

People who understand what virtue is (dispositions/habits to do good) and who assiduously work to increase their virtue will on average respond to moral choices toward choosing (and toward doing) the good.

That's not random.

You know THOSF, when I received my executive clemency restoring my right to vote, it looked like an important document, all fancy with the state seal, etc.. So one day I was joking with this Notre Dame grad about his diploma on a wall. I told him if I framed mine and hung it on a wall next to his, people would skip over his, and ask some serious questions about mine! He laughed. 
I locked that document up with other paperwork that tells my life as a kid to today, so future grandchildren can one day reflect on the old man they came to love. Hopefully when they hit hard times, they realize that a man was made to fight from his first breath, to never give up on the greatest of all gifts, life itself.
Sadly, some states never do restore the right to vote after completion of sentence, it's almost a modern day Jim Crow law. But if one chooses to be a criminal as I once did, they knew it came with a price, one of accountability. Sad to see a kid today take that road, I tell them straight up.

Alberta conservatives lived through the nightmare of the federal split on the right. That is why the merger happened so quickly on the provincial level.

The NDP are despised here in Alberta. They won election thanks to vote splitting on the right, plus the collapse of the Alberta Liberal Party on the left. Hello MilesD,

My impression is that comments can be "disappeared" through various mechanisms, none of them to do with "a glitch".

1. The laypersons who do the initial reviews trash them as badly uncivil posts, when they are not, and it does not see the light of day on the baord.
2. The laypersons let it get posted, but it gets flagged by others as offensive (when it is not, it simply grates on their sociopolitical preferences), and in some silly fashion gets deleted when it ought not get deleted.
3. I suspect the columnists and journalists themselves have access, should they want it, to fast-track intervention with those in charge of board moderation.

I am not suggesting it is a Globe and Mail editor who is behind what is happening.

But whoever is behind it, come on, surely you have noticed that in some subject areas, lots of posts get "disappeared" for reasons that have nothing to do with "civility" of written content (examples, anything related to Islam or indigenous natives).
Do you know they aren't?

When I am back home in the islands, my absolute favorite place to visit is Chinatown- specifically the marketplace mentioned in the article. For most of the year, I am situated in Washington D.C. where there is something to be missed in the Chinatown there. The independent stores that once lined these streets have been overtaken by chain-stores. The Chinatown in D.C. is desperately trying to hold on to its identity by placing Chinese characters above chain-stores such as Chipotle and AMC theaters. I did not appreciate how unique and how much value Honolulu's Chinatown has to the community until I moved away from it. It absolutely should be cherished because of its multiculturalism. The cheap/delicious produce is a nice bonus :)

I am from Pendeton, OR and lost my employment when the state decided to close the psychiatric hospital here.  Tax payers should be outraged by this, as the closure of this facility wastes all the tax dollars spent constructing this hospital.  Not to mention the thousands of dollars that were spent moving employees from Pendleton if they decided to uproot their families in order to keep their state employment.  This of course does nothing to account for the lost tax revenue from the future wages earned by these employees and the dollars that they spend annually in the community.

I've been in this house for over 29 years, and I've out-lived five of the trees I planted, including a cherry tree and a peach tree, both destroyed by wet snowfalls, an aspen that uprooted and fell across the driveway after heavy rains, and another I took out when it became diseased, then a third one I had an arborist take out because its branches were encroaching on the house.  He should have warned me of what happens when you cut down live aspens ... their freaking root systems are almost indestructable!  The next summer, I had about 300 Aspen shoots sprout up in my front yard!  I had to research a chemical to kill off the root system.  The world's largest living organism is an Aspen forest in Utah that has a root system that has survived a number of forest fires.

I still have a couple of blue spruce I planted when we moved in that are taller than the house, as well as an ash in the back that's that tall. I'm afraid I've created three lightening rods.

Our father Frank Nyman was on the survey crew that surveyed the Chair 1 route in winter of 1959 (or thereabouts).  They planned to camp on the mountain. Survey methods were a theodolite and a steel tape.  Of course..it rained hard and the soaked surveyors abandoned plans to camp on the route for the warm beds of the inn down below. They completed the survey in the next few days and he told me that the final chair alignment closely followed their survey path.  Frank included this story in a self published account of  50 years of Alaska Engineering. 

Most of us skiers adore Chair One, not only for the ski memories but for the wonderful upper mountain (top to midway) powder runs offered by the midway station. This strategic location allowed for uploading without descending to the bottom of the hill. Long Live Chair One! Looking for a renaissance of the route and a new midway someday.  Thanks Alyeska Resort for your continued improvement of skier experience at Alyeska!

HI, independently.  Your comment about "demands for relief" reminds me of what my grandmother told me.  In the 1930s, as a single mother of 3, she rented a large home in Vancouver.  Owners had returned to the UK.  She operated the place as a boarding house.  She went to the property management office and told the reps she couldn't pay the rent.  Sure the house was full, but most people were on "relief" and couldn't Pay her.

"Don't worry, Mrs. Thorne," the property managers told her. "Just take good care of the place and pay us when you can..."  Went on for years that way.

You're a great teacher, lorenzo!  I myself put in 40 years before retiring and yes, I did it all:  club advisor, class advisor, night school teacher, department chair, etc., etc.  When I got in back in the mid 70's, there was actually a teacher GLUT as opposed to a shortage.  So, if you managed to get a teaching job, you TOOK it, no matter where, and you APPRECIATED it!  When the principal asked for favors such as being an  advisor, coach, or night school, you said YES, because you almost felt like you owed it to him/her.  "NO" was not in our vocabulary.  In my last few years, I saw many young teachers whose only answer seemed to be "NO."  Reason?  I believe the shortage has a lot to do with it.  If the principal asks "too much," just transfer to an "easier" school!  Some don't even want to chaperone a single event like prom.  Sure, there are a few like you left, but numbers are dwindling.  I fear for education when millenials take over.

That is not what the Surgeon General's report on suicide in the Canadian Force suggests. On the contrary, now that enough time has passed since the end of the mission for major mental health disorders to have by and large presented themselves, and and now that enough time has passed for decent longitudinal research to have been conducted, the data DOES exist to suggest there there is a statistically significantly higher risk of suicide among male army veterans of Afghanistan. Note also that this data is limited to those who are still serving in the military, who will tend to be the most functional on average. Veterans who have released from the military are NOT covered by the stats. The data does not yet exist for that; anecdotally it is appearing to many of us who pay attention that the suicide rate for released Afghanistan veterans is likely considerably higher. than it is for those still serving. VAC has pledged to have this data for December 2017.

Nice column. Regarding: the goal, of making sure that folks face comparable tax treatment whether or not they have a corporation, is a good one

The problem here is that there two types of corporations in the mix. There are the ones that exist primarily to benefit from passive income tax treatment. The other set is comprised of the real operating companies established by active  entrepreneurs who built a business and want a rainy day fund of available capital to survive a downturn or reinvest when the time is right. The proposed measures leave no incentive to build this rainy fund and it has implications far beyond the much hyped tax fairness outcomes. 

I have not seen any estimate by the Finance department of the breakdown between the two. In any event, do we really want to shut down these small business rainy day funds? What will it mean during the next recession? More job losses? More EI? 

The Minister should probably distinguish between the two and start over.

The show is not wrong.

1605-Port Royal is founded as a French trading settlement. 
1607-The French government revokes the trading license; everyone goes home. Port Royal is abandoned for 3 years.
****1608-Quebec City is founded****
1610-The French return to Port Royal to resume trading.
1613-The English burn down Port Royal. It remains abandoned for 19 years.
****During this time, Quebec City continues to grow; more settlers and missionaries arrive. The first children are born in Quebec City.****
1632-Port Royal is re-re-established 8 KM away from the original site.

So for 22 of its first 27 years, Port Royal was abandoned. This does not contradict the show's claim that Quebec City was the first "permanent" European settlement.

Deal?

Good question, Little Dickie.  There were two main reasons: 
1. Some German leaders were concerned about a possible Allied counter-attack;  the British and French still offered resistance in neighbouring areas. 

2. There was much Nazi high command disagreement.  Some commanders wanted the attack, some did not.  Hitler felt HE had to prevail...and he prevaricated. 

3. The Germans did renew the attack--but the delay cost them dearly.  By the time their forces mobilized, most of the men had been taken off the beach. 

No question that this delay saved a British army.  However, it came at a significant cost: scores of men lost in combat and during the evacuation, abandoning 272 ships, 177 aircraft and 2,400 guns.

Many readers remember the argument that the tax revenue from Measure 97 would actually come, not from the corporations, but from Oregon consumers when the cost of the tax was added to the price of goods.  That was a sound argument......profits may not "trickle down", but, I guarantee you, increased costs do.

A 20% tariff on goods from Mexico doesn't mean the Mexican government will be "paying for building THE WALL"....not hardly.  It means the cost of goods coming from Mexico will increase by 20% at the point of import....usually at a wholesale level.  That increased cost will be "passed along" and eventually reach the "end user".....the American consumer of the imported goods.  It may have the net effect of a "protective tariff" by making American products or crops more competitive on the market, but it does not constitute "Mexico paying for the wall."  

Additionally, of course, such moves often lead to "tariff wars" as the impacted nation reacts "in kind" with a tariff.  Gary Crum
Consequences... consequences....

I grant that dense urban housing is much more energy efficient than the number of small houses required for the same number of people. I don't really think anyone's arguing otherwise.

The issue is in balancing the goal of increasing density with the fact that a lot of people find actually living in places of such density to be unacceptable. In effect, the goal requires people to be harmed in order to implement it. You can argue that it's inevitable, or that "eggs must be broken", or whatever, but it's still real people really being hurt. It might help to be sensitive to that.

Personally, I think that increasing density is regrettable but inevitable, so it's worth trying to minimize the harm. EE is one attempt at doing that, but arguments and fights from those being hurt are also part of the process -- and might help to make EE into something better overall.

Having experienced both healthcare systems I can say that I'd never trade ours for theirs. And I say so as someone who, due to the good fortune of my employment, have had access to the best the US has to offer.  

Some years ago my wife had a very bad accident while we were on vacation in the US. She required immediate and complex surgery to repair a badly broken leg. Fortunately, the local hospital specialized in orthopedic surgery. The doctors performed brilliantly. No one asked whether we had insurance: they went to work immediately and saved her leg.

The hospital was like a 5-star hotel. People came from miles around to eat there, the food was so good. 

They put me up in an adjacent suite for 4 days. We stayed over a weekend and were one of just 3 people in a 45-bed state-of-the art facility.

We were then given a bill - US$125,000. Thankfully my insurance covered it.

Yes, Americans with money have the greatest healthcare in history. But it is just not right.

The biggest problem with polling is determining who will and who won't show up.  Usually the polls are often accurate of the general population but when supporters of certain parties show up in greater numbers than others they can be wrong.  Also the bigger the undecided, the more likely a mistake as undecided votes can and often break heavily in one direction rather than follow the general distribution.  A low undecided and high voter turnout will tend to yield more accurate results than high undecided and low turnout (See Alberta 2012 for an example of this).

We've heard about the hunting, fishing, and all the valuable ecosystems and species we'll lose if the Elliott is sold and logged. As a retired timber cruiser, I'm concerned with the money we'll lose if the Elliott is sold to a private company.

In 2014, the state sold three Elliott Forest tracts to Seneca Timber for only $1,895,000, less than a third of the appraised value of $6,000,00, based on domestic log prices, not export log prices. For years before, Seneca  bought sales of 115 year old Elliott timber sales at often half what younger second growth sells for.

If the state sells the Elliott, worth 400 million instead of their 220 million dollar asking price, they'll have sold off 80% of the original 3.4 million acres originally dedicated to Oregon by the federal government to fund schools. Had the State Land Board wisely managed the 3.4 million acres instead of deeding them away to private interests, at similar unfair discounts, we'd have far more money in today's school fund.

Visual concerns for the neighborhood are separate from any RF concerns. I can see visually not wanting that metal tree in your backyard.

The energy from your cellphone, especially if held against your head, is FAR higher than the dose you get from a cell tower a quarter mile away and 150' up. Wi-fi devices in houses are also worse than that tower. The wiring in your house also emits a pretty good field. 

The key is that the intensity of radiation decreases by the square of the distance. A phone held to your ear is the worst case scenario imaginable. Yet most people do that without thinking, bathing their brains in RF radiation. 

RF radiation behaves like most things, from arsenic to medicine to nuclear radiation to sugar -- a little won't hurt you. A extremely large amount will (like standing a few feet in front of a military radar). There is no evidence that exposure damage is cumulative. 

If you are still concerned, get rid of your cellphone and wi-fi. Not the tower.

"It could even be a payment to cover open market policy purchase of the employees' choice rather than an employer-selected policy."
Mike Rosen mentioned that in a column of his. I like the idea.
Rosen was trying to make the case that if employers covered married employees' health insurance premiums and single employees' health insurance premiums, then, in his mind, married employees were receiving more compensation for the same work as single employees.
I don't know if I completely buy that argument, and if Rosen truly believes in the free market, then what employers offer their employees shouldn't affect him.
But, I do like the idea of employers offering every employee a salary plus X amount for them to go out and buy health insurance.
As I understand it, though, if an employer covers an employee's health insurance premium, that is not taxable income. But, if the employer offers X amount for the employee to get insurance in the private market, that "X" is deemed taxable income.

I was told when I spent a lot of time in the Aleutians that there was a plague of otters that wiped out all the clams around Atka in the 60's. One could find huge razor valves on Korovin beach, but no clams. My Aleut mentor, Nick Nevzorof, had a string of dungy pots that hadn't been used for years because they weren't any to fish for. The medical system, like most other endevours is inefficient profit driven and needs overhaul.

The rise of collaborative practices, which might be beneficial, if you were able to see your regular physician within a reasonable period of time instead of one of many physicians who never get to know you and therefore are tempted to intervene unnecessarily to avoid error.  Per visit remuneration is also a mistake typically limiting visits to 15 minutes; some patients need only a few minutes others may need an hour or more.

The key to good medicine is to have a physician who knows you well and can, over time, recognize changes that may need investigation or intervention (often just exercise or diet).

Osler said that "the first duty of a physician is to tell his patients not to take medicine".  Times have changed since his day but his observation is a wise one.  Patients are responsible for their own health; physicians are their consultants.

The Boeing 747, along with smaller planes the DC-10 and L-1011 really was the tool that made Hawaii tourism come alive. With its capacity (3x as much as the first generation of jets like the DC-8 and 707) along with equivalent speed of the first jets, the ability of just about anyone to board a plane and come to Hawaii for a vacation became very real to a large swath of the American population. Of course today the economics of air travel are quite different - this plane was built at a time when revenue on a route was assured through government regulation. However, the significance of what this plane did for Hawaii will live on long after the last 747 in American operation heads to the plane graveyard.

Looking at auto-trader in Ontario, there are 2015 Micras for sale for $7,500. This is substantial depreciation when you factor in dealer fees (delivery and such) on top of sales price. So you can expect 30%+ depreciation in the first year. This is crazy bad.

The single most important Transit Project in GTA is the Downtown Relief Line (long, up to Sheppard).  That is the only way we can relieve the imminent over-capacity at Bloor and Yonge.   As a point of comparison, more people live in York region and are far better suited to take transit (density, proximity)  than all of SWO (possibly excluding K-W which could be served by improvements to GO service).    There will be a far greater ROI from than DRL than this plan.   

Can we please stay focused on the priority?

Of note, from my experience, transit hubs not only tie transit modes together but are also a destination (such as a City Center) where people walk to where they live, work or play.   

I don't think the Pearson Transit Hub is a bad idea.  It just needs to be prioritized relative to other potential transit investments.

Why don’t they work?  Because they tend to discourage construction of new rental buildings. By restricting supply they make the market tighter and, perversely, increase the pressure to raise rents.  They also discourage landlords from maintaining or improving their properties - so the quality of the existing inventory declines.  And those outcomes are exactly the opposite of what we need to do here.  We do not have enough rental inventory in this state and the problem literally gets worse every day.  Our population is growing by 31 people every day.  Two thirds of that is natural growth: 21 more babies are born here every day than the number of people who die.  That’s 76,650 new locally born new residents in the next decade.  That’s why the state Department of Business Economic Development and Tourism has stated that we need roughly 65,000 new housing units in the next ten years and it’s why the Legislature this year resolved that we need 22,000 new affordable rental units by 2026.

Yes, there have been many times in history when media sources have been misleading (Bronson probably will remind us soon about The Washington Post and the Iraq war), and, as terrible as those cases have been, I don't think we can disregard the many, many more times that journalists have led us toward light and truth (Spotlight is a good recent example, http://spotlightthefilm.com/). That said, journalists still are responsible for what they publish. It's not enough to just report what someone anonymous said. ... And there does seem to be way more punditry in today's media (cable news, especially), which gives the impression that everyone has an opinion, when that's really not the important part (truth is!).

It is heartbreaking to see Venezuelans fleeing in all directions depending on what is close to them - Brazil, Colombia, Curacao, Cuba, Haiti, Trinidad, Peru and those with means, of course, the US and even Canada. Yet, most prefer Colombia because of the language and because they need no visa to enter the country. This article truly expresses many of the frustrations I've seen there while working and helping people. But violence and government repression have escalated so much this year that even NGOs, Human rights activists, diplomats, and almost all foreigners I encountered there are now leaving the country. Just getting a flight ticket there is a real nightmare. 

P.S. The journalists that are covering day-to-day events across Venezuela are some of the bravest people out there. It is not just reporting; it's even finding something to eat and a safe place to stay for a few hours before the next violence comes out. Great for the Globe and Mail to cover these stories.
